did.abstract: The collection comprises two disbound late-nineteenth-century Brooklyn police precinct ledgers containing handwritten daily entries recording routine activities such as roll calls as well as occasional reports of criminal incidents and accidents.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased by Brooklyn Historical Society from About Books with funds donated by Jim Rossman, 2016.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Each of the two volumes is stored in its own box. Entries in the volumes are in chronological order.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Brooklyn police ledgers, 2016.019, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.p: Minimally processed to the collection level.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The first volume covers the period December 1868 to January 1869 within the precinct of Captain George R. Rhodes and contains records of routine activities such as roll calls and inspections of sleeping quarters, as well as reports of crimes and other events. Also included is a "Roll of the Force," which lists policemen alphabetically by name and includes their age, date of appointment, and residence.

The second volume covers the period April 8, 1898 to May 30, 1898 and is inscribed inside the front cover with the name "Police Surgeon Charles H. Terry." It contains records of routine activities such as roll calls and uniform inspections, as well as complaints against police officers (largely for absenteeism) and reports of incidents of crimes and accidents. References to postings in various parks (such as Washington, Highland, Carroll, Winthrop, and Bushwick) and to accidents in Prospect Park appear frequently and indicate that this volume may relate to a park precinct.
